msContents.summary: Fragments of The Amduat. Two plates.

physDesc.p: These plates were previous describes as being from the "Litany to the Sun", however the illustrations bear great resemblance to those from the eleventh and twelth hours of the Amduat, albeit in a condensed format and with different text.

supportDesc.extent: Two plates. Plate one is a single fragment: 202312 Plate two is five fragments, with the measurements given being for the largest and smallest fragments respectively 215163 410

handDesc.handNote: Likely written by one scribe, all in black ink

decoDesc.decoNote:
Basic illustrations all in black ink. Plate one has two registers. On the upper register, a winged deity stands in front of a snake with legs, an animal-headed goddess spits fire, a deity holds a wedjat eye over a fan, and two goddesses holding flails sit on serpents and reach towards a large nTr hieroglyph. On the lower register, a reclining deity is spat on by a snake being held aloft by three gods, and Ra sits in his barque with an animal-headed god holding an oar behind him, and a falcon with a solar crown perches in front of him.
Plate two has two registers. On the upper register, five animal-headed gods stand holding oars. On the lower register, a line of gods and goddesses stand and hold a rope.
Both plates are illustrated in black ink only.

history.acquisition: Given by the Rev. G. J. Chester, 1890

recordHist.source: Summary description abbreviated from the Bodleian Libraries' unpublished card catalogue for otherwise-undescribed manuscripts, available in the Charles Wendell David Reading Room.

availability.p: This item may only be consulted by prior arrangement with a curator. To make an application, please click the request button above. When your request is received, you will be asked to contact the relevant person.
